beginner.title: The Rejection Collection
beginner.instructions: Make 10 cold outreach attempts today with the goal of collecting rejections, not closes. Track each rejection. This reframes failure as progress.
beginner.success_criteria: Complete 10 outreach attempts and log each response (or non-response)

beginner.title: Mirror Practice
beginner.instructions: Practice Chris Voss's mirroring technique in 3 real conversations today. Simply repeat the last 1-3 words of what someone says as a question. Notice how it encourages them to elaborate.
beginner.success_criteria: Used mirroring 3+ times and noted the responses in your journal

beginner.title: Objection Scripting
beginner.instructions: Write down the 5 most common objections you hear. For each one, write 2-3 response options. Practice saying them out loud until they feel natural.
beginner.success_criteria: 5 objections with 2-3 responses each, practiced verbally

intermediate.title: Record and Review
intermediate.instructions: Record your next sales call (with permission). Listen back and critique: Where did you talk too much? Miss buying signals? Let objections derail you? Create 3 specific improvements.
intermediate.success_criteria: One recorded call with written self-critique and 3 action items

intermediate.title: Role Play Gauntlet
intermediate.instructions: Partner with someone (colleague, friend, coach). Have them throw your top 5 objections at you in rapid fire. Practice responding for 5 minutes per objection. Get feedback.
intermediate.success_criteria: Complete 5 objection role plays with documented feedback

intermediate.title: Zombie Lead Revival
intermediate.instructions: Go through your CRM/contacts and find 10 'dead' leads you gave up on. Send a creative re-engagement message to each. Track responses.
intermediate.success_criteria: 10 re-engagement messages sent with different approaches tested

advanced.title: Straight Line Mastery
advanced.instructions: Map out your complete sales process as a 'straight line' from opening to close. Identify every point where prospects fall off. Create specific recovery tactics for each dropout point.
advanced.success_criteria: Visual sales process map with recovery tactics documented

advanced.title: Tactical Empathy Deep Dive
advanced.instructions: Before your next high-stakes conversation, write a full 'accusation audit' - list every negative thing the other person might think about you or your offer. Then craft labels for each one to defuse them proactively.
advanced.success_criteria: Complete accusation audit with 5+ proactive labels written and delivered

advanced.title: Build Your Sales Playbook
advanced.instructions: Create a comprehensive sales playbook: ideal customer profile, opening scripts, qualifying questions, objection responses, closing techniques, follow-up sequences. This becomes your training manual.
advanced.success_criteria: Written playbook covering all phases of your sales process

advanced.title: Complex Deal Stakeholder Mapping
advanced.instructions: Take your largest active opportunity and map every stakeholder involved. For each person, document: their role in the decision, what they care about, their biggest concern, your relationship strength (1-5), and your specific strategy to win them over. Identify gaps and create action items.
advanced.success_criteria: Complete stakeholder map with 5+ stakeholders documented and specific action plan for each

advanced.title: Enterprise Multi-Threading Exercise
advanced.instructions: Select a target enterprise account you want to win. Research 5-7 people across different functions (sales, ops, finance, IT, executive). For each, craft a personalized outreach message that speaks to their specific role and concerns. Execute a coordinated multi-touch campaign over 2 weeks.
advanced.success_criteria: 5+ personalized messages sent across multiple roles, with tracking of responses and next steps

advanced.title: Build Your Predictable Revenue Engine
advanced.instructions: Design your own outbound sales system: Define your ICP (ideal customer profile), build a target account list of 50 companies, create a 10-12 touch prospecting cadence with templates for each touch, define handoff criteria to closing, and set up tracking metrics. This is your sales machine blueprint.
advanced.success_criteria: Complete system documented: ICP definition, 50 target accounts, full cadence with templates, handoff criteria, and KPI dashboard

masters.name: Jordan Belfort
key_principles: The only thing standing between you and your goal is the story you keep telling yourself.
Sales is a transfer of emotion. You must believe before they can.
Tonality is 90% of communication. Words are just 10%.
Every sale has five basic obstacles: no need, no money, no hurry, no desire, no trust.
Act as if you're a wealthy person, and you'll become one.
Logic makes people think. Emotion makes people act.
daily_practices: Practice your pitch with power and conviction
Record yourself and analyze your tonality
Handle 10 objections out loud daily

worked_examples.title: The Straight Line Cold Call
worked_examples.scenario: You need to make cold calls but keep getting blown off in the first 10 seconds.
worked_examples.framework_applied: Straight Line System - Open, Qualify, Close while managing certainty levels
step_by_step: Tonality first: Sound like you belong on the phone, not like a telemarketer. Confident, curious, direct.
Pattern interrupt: Don't start with 'Hi, is this a bad time?' - Start with value or a question that makes them think
Quick value statement: In one sentence, explain why they should keep listening
Qualify fast: Within 30 seconds, determine if they have the need, authority, and ability to buy
Build certainty: On the product (does it work?), on you (can I trust this person?), on the company (is this legitimate?)
Loop objections: When they object, don't argue - acknowledge, deflect, and return to your line
Close with urgency: Give them a reason to act now, not 'think about it'
worked_examples.outcome: Cold calls go from <10% answer rate to 30%+ by using proper tonality and pattern interrupts

scripts_templates.title: Cold Call Opening Script
scripts_templates.context: Use when making B2B cold calls to get past the first 10 seconds
scripts_templates.template:
[ENTHUSIASTIC TONE]
"Hey [NAME], this is [YOUR NAME] with [COMPANY].

Hey, did I catch you at a bad time?"

[WHEN THEY SAY 'YES' OR 'WHAT IS THIS ABOUT']

"I figured. Look, I'll be brief - I'm calling because [SPECIFIC REASON RELEVANT TO THEM].

I've been working with [SIMILAR COMPANIES/ROLES] who were struggling with [PAIN POINT].

I'm not sure if that's even on your radar, but if it is, I have an idea that might help.

Would you be opposed to hearing it?"
scripts_templates.example_filled:
"Hey Sarah, this is Mike with GrowthForce.

Hey, did I catch you at a bad time?"

[She says: 'Yeah, what is this about?']

"I figured. Look, I'll be brief - I'm calling because I noticed you recently raised Series A.

I've been working with post-Series A startups who were struggling to build their first outbound sales motion.

I'm not sure if that's even on your radar, but if it is, I have an idea that might help.

Would you be opposed to hearing it?"

scripts_templates.title: Tonality Practice Script
scripts_templates.context: Use to practice the three core tonalities that close deals
scripts_templates.template:
TONALITY 1: CERTAINTY
Practice saying: "This is absolutely going to work for you."
[Record yourself. Does it sound certain or hesitant?]

TONALITY 2: SCARCITY
Practice saying: "We only have a few spots left this quarter."
[Does it sound urgent or desperate?]

TONALITY 3: REASONABLE
Practice saying: "Fair enough, I totally understand."
[Does it sound empathetic or dismissive?]

Now string them together:
"I totally understand your concern [REASONABLE]. That said, this is going to work [CERTAINTY], and we should probably move forward while [SCARCITY]."
scripts_templates.example_filled:
[After 10 practice rounds, recording and listening back]
Certainty: Now sounds confident, not arrogant
Scarcity: Now sounds urgent, not pushy
Reasonable: Now sounds empathetic, not weak
Full delivery smooth and natural

masters.name: Grant Cardone
key_principles: 10X your goals and 10X your actions.
Success is your duty, obligation, and responsibility.
Most people fail because they're not taking enough action.
Be obsessed or be average.
The fortune is in the follow-up. Follow up until they buy or die.
Never lower your target. Increase your actions.
daily_practices: Make 10X the calls you think you need

worked_examples.title: The 10X Follow-Up System
worked_examples.scenario: You send proposals but only follow up once or twice, then give up.
step_by_step: Diagnose: Most salespeople give up after 1-2 follow-ups. 80% of sales require 5+ touches.
Commit to 10X: Instead of 2 follow-ups, commit to 12-15 touches over 30 days
Vary the channel: Call, email, LinkedIn, text, video message, voicemail drop
Add value each time: Don't just 'check in' - share relevant content, insights, case studies
Track obsessively: Know exactly where each prospect is and when you last touched them
Never stop: Move to monthly follow-up after 30 days, but never fully give up
worked_examples.outcome: Close rate increases 30-40% just from systematic follow-up. Deals that seemed dead come back to life.

masters.name: Chris Voss
masters.expertise: FBI negotiation, tactical empathy, hostage techniques
key_principles: Never split the difference. Fight for the best outcome.
Tactical empathy is understanding the feelings and mindset of another.
No is the start of the negotiation, not the end.
Mirror words to build rapport and get more information.
Label emotions: 'It seems like...' 'It sounds like...'
The person who has learned to disagree without being disagreeable has the upper hand.
daily_practices: Use mirroring in 3 conversations today
Label someone's emotion out loud
Ask 'How am I supposed to do that?' instead of saying no

worked_examples.title: Tactical Empathy to Handle Price Objection
worked_examples.scenario: Prospect says 'That's too expensive' and you need to navigate without dropping price.
step_by_step: Don't defend the price immediately. Pause.
Label their concern: 'It sounds like budget is really tight right now.'
Wait for 'that's right' (not 'you're right' - that's dismissive)
Ask calibrated question: 'What would make this work for you?'
Mirror their response: They say 'Well, we'd need payment terms.' You say 'Payment terms?'
Label again: 'It seems like cash flow timing is the real issue here.'
Offer creative solution: 'What if we structured this as quarterly payments?'
worked_examples.outcome: Full price preserved, deal closed with creative terms. Client feels heard, not pressured.

scripts_templates.title: Top 5 Objection Responses Using Tactical Empathy
scripts_templates.context: Handle the most common sales objections with FBI-trained techniques
scripts_templates.template:
OBJECTION 1: "It's too expensive"
- Label: "It sounds like you're concerned about the investment."
- Calibrated Q: "What would you need to see to feel confident about the ROI?"
- Reframe: "How much is NOT solving this problem costing you?"

OBJECTION 2: "I need to think about it"
- Label: "It seems like there's something holding you back."
- Calibrated Q: "What's the one thing that would make this a clear yes?"
- Push: "What's your gut telling you?"

OBJECTION 3: "I need to talk to my [partner/boss/team]"
- Label: "It sounds like you're not the only decision-maker here."
- Calibrated Q: "What concerns do you think they'll have?"
- Prepare: "How can I help you make the case to them?"

OBJECTION 4: "We're already working with someone"
- Label: "It sounds like you have a relationship that's working."
- Calibrated Q: "What would need to change for you to consider alternatives?"
- Plant seed: "If things ever change, what would be the trigger?"

OBJECTION 5: "Now's not a good time"
- Label: "It seems like you've got a lot on your plate right now."
- Calibrated Q: "When would be a better time to revisit this?"
- Create urgency: "What happens if this waits 6 months?"
scripts_templates.example_filled:
[Prospect: 'It's too expensive']

You: [Pause 3 seconds] "It sounds like you're concerned about the investment."

Prospect: "Yeah, it's just more than we budgeted."

You: "More than you budgeted..."

Prospect: "Right, we allocated $10k and this is $15k."

You: "What would you need to see to feel confident this $15k delivers $50k in value?"

Prospect: "I'd need to know it actually works."

You: "It seems like you've been burned before by promises that didn't deliver."

Prospect: "That's right."

You: "What if we structured a pilot program with performance guarantees?"

scripts_templates.title: Accusation Audit Template
scripts_templates.context: Use before high-stakes negotiations to defuse objections before they're raised
scripts_templates.template:
NEGATIVE THINGS THEY MIGHT THINK:
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___
4. ___
5. ___

PROACTIVE LABELS TO DEFUSE EACH:
1. "You probably think..."
2. "It might seem like..."
3. "You might be wondering..."
4. "I know it looks like..."
5. "You're probably feeling..."

DELIVERY: Front-load these at the START of the conversation
scripts_templates.example_filled:
NEGATIVE THINGS THEY MIGHT THINK:
1. This is another salesperson trying to hit quota
2. The price is going to be outrageous
3. They don't understand our specific situation
4. This will be a waste of time
5. They're going to be pushy

PROACTIVE LABELS:

3. "It might seem like we don't understand your specific challenges..."
4. "You're probably wondering if this is going to be worth your time..."
5. "I know it might feel like I'm going to be pushy..."

[Then pause and let them respond. Most will say 'No, no...' and open up]

masters.name: Zig Ziglar
key_principles: You can have everything in life you want, if you help enough other people get what they want.
Stop selling. Start helping.
Every sale has five obstacles: no need, no money, no hurry, no desire, no trust.
People don't buy for logical reasons. They buy for emotional reasons.
You don't have to be great to start, but you have to start to be great.
F.E.A.R. has two meanings: Forget Everything And Run, or Face Everything And Rise.
daily_practices: Find out what your prospect really wants
Focus on serving, not selling
Build genuine relationships before asking for anything

worked_examples.title: The Helper's Close
worked_examples.scenario: You're in a sales conversation but it feels pushy and transactional.
step_by_step: Shift your mindset: You're not here to sell, you're here to solve their problem
Ask about their goals: 'What would success look like for you?'
Understand their obstacles: 'What's standing in the way right now?'
Connect genuinely: Find something you relate to in their situation
Offer help: 'Based on what you've told me, here's how I might be able to help...'
Let them decide: 'Does this sound like something worth exploring?'
Follow up regardless: Whether they buy or not, send them something valuable
worked_examples.outcome: Conversion goes up because you're not 'selling' - you're having a genuine conversation about their needs

scripts_templates.title: The Needs Discovery Script
scripts_templates.context: Use at the start of any sales conversation to understand what they really want
scripts_templates.template:
"Before I tell you anything about what we do, I'd love to understand your situation better."

1. "What made you take this call/meeting today?"
2. "What does success look like for you in [area]?"
3. "What's working well right now?"
4. "What's the biggest challenge you're facing?"
5. "If we could wave a magic wand, what would you want to be different?"
6. "What have you already tried?"
7. "What's this costing you - in time, money, or stress?"
8. "Who else is affected by this?"

"Based on what you've shared, let me explain how we might be able to help..."
scripts_templates.example_filled:
"Before I tell you anything about our coaching program, I'd love to understand your situation better."

1. "What made you book this call today?" - "I saw your content and it resonated"
2. "What does success look like for you?" - "Closing more deals without feeling sleazy"
3. "What's working well?" - "I'm good at building rapport, but weak at closing"
4. "Biggest challenge?" - "I have lots of conversations but few convert"
5. "Magic wand?" - "I'd be confident asking for the sale"
6. "What have you tried?" - "Read some books, nothing stuck"
7. "What's it costing you?" - "Probably $50k+ in missed commissions"
8. "Who else is affected?" - "My family - I'm stressed about income"

"Based on what you've shared, it sounds like you need a structured closing framework. Let me show you exactly how we help with that..."

masters.name: Jeb Blount
key_principles: The enduring mantra of all top salespeople is: One more call.
Prospecting is the lifeblood of sales success.
Rejection is not failure. It's just part of the process.
The three Ps: Protect prime selling time, Prioritize prospects, Push through resistance.
The more you prospect, the luckier you get.
Your pipeline is your lifeline. Never stop filling it.
daily_practices: Protect your first 2 hours for outreach only
Make prospecting non-negotiable daily
Aim for 'nos' - they lead to 'yeses'

worked_examples.title: The Fanatical Prospecting Block
worked_examples.scenario: Your pipeline is feast or famine because you only prospect when desperate.
step_by_step: Block sacred time: First 2 hours of your day = prospecting. No exceptions.
Prepare the night before: List of names, numbers, and email drafts ready to go
Start immediately: Don't check email, don't warm up - just start dialing
Track velocity: How many dials/emails per hour? Increase by 10% weekly
One more call: At the end of each session, do ONE MORE call
Never negotiate: This time is sacred. Meetings, emails, fires - all wait.
Compound daily: 2 hours × 5 days × 50 weeks = 500 hours of prospecting = full pipeline forever
worked_examples.outcome: Pipeline becomes consistently full. No more feast/famine cycles. Income stabilizes and grows.

masters.name: Jill Konrath
key_principles: Selling is about creating value, not pitching products.
Buyers are crazy-busy. Respect their time or lose the deal.
Be a resource, not a pest. Bring insights, not brochures.
Get to the decision-maker fast. Don't get stuck in gatekeepers.
Your job is to make it easy for them to buy, not hard for them to say no.
Complex sales require mapping the buying process, not just pushing your sales process.
daily_practices: Research prospects deeply before reaching out
Lead with insights and value, not product features
Focus on the business problem, not your solution

worked_examples.title: Breaking Into Complex Enterprise Accounts
worked_examples.scenario: You're trying to sell to a large enterprise but can't get past gatekeepers.
step_by_step: Research the company's strategic priorities (earnings calls, press releases, LinkedIn)
Identify the pain: What challenge is costing them money or opportunity?
Map the power structure: Who owns this problem? Who has budget authority?
Craft an executive-level message: Skip features, speak to business outcomes
Example: 'I noticed you're expanding in APAC. Companies like yours typically struggle with X. We help reduce Y by 40%.'
Request a brief conversation (15 min) to share insights, not pitch
Bring a diagnostic framework or industry insights they don't have
Position as a resource: 'Even if we don't work together, this might be helpful'
worked_examples.outcome: You get in the door because you're bringing value, not asking for time. Decision-makers respond to business impact.

worked_examples.title: Navigating Multi-Stakeholder Sales
worked_examples.scenario: You have one champion, but the deal requires approval from multiple stakeholders you haven't met.
step_by_step: With your champion, map all stakeholders: Who has a say? What do they care about?
For each stakeholder: What's their win? What's their risk?
CFO cares about ROI and risk. CTO cares about implementation and integration. End-users care about ease of use.
Create tailored talking points for your champion to use with each stakeholder
Build a business case document that addresses each stakeholder's concerns
Request to present directly to key stakeholders - don't rely solely on your champion
In presentation, address each person's priorities explicitly
Example: 'Sarah, I know integration complexity is your concern. Here's how we handle that...'
worked_examples.outcome: Deal moves forward because every stakeholder feels heard and their concerns are addressed. Your champion has ammunition to sell internally.

key_principles: Predictable Revenue: Separate prospecting from closing. Specialists beat generalists.

Seed, Net, Spear: Three types of leads require three different motions.

worked_examples.title: Building a Predictable Revenue Engine
worked_examples.scenario: Your sales are feast or famine. You need consistent pipeline.
step_by_step: Separate roles: Prospectors (SDRs) find and qualify. Closers (AEs) sell.
Define your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP): Company size, industry, role, pain
Build a targeted list: 100-500 companies that match ICP perfectly
Create a cadence: Day 1 email, Day 3 call, Day 5 LinkedIn, Day 7 email, etc.
SDRs goal: Book qualified meetings, not close deals
Qualified = has the problem, has budget, has authority, has timeline
Track metrics: Calls made, emails sent, conversations, meetings booked
Optimize weekly: What messaging works? What doesn't? Iterate.
worked_examples.outcome: Pipeline becomes predictable. You can forecast: X activity → Y meetings → Z deals. Scale by adding more SDRs.

worked_examples.title: Cold Calling 2.0 - Targeted Outreach
worked_examples.scenario: You're wasting time calling the wrong people at the wrong companies.
step_by_step: SEED (Inbound): People who come to you. Nurture with content and follow-up.
NET (Referrals): Ask every happy customer for introductions. This is your best source.
SPEAR (Outbound): Target specific accounts you want to win.
For SPEAR: Don't spray. Pick 10 dream accounts. Research deeply.
Multi-thread: Find 3-5 people at each target account. Reach out to all.
Personalize: Reference company news, mutual connections, specific pain
Example: 'Saw you're hiring 50 engineers. That usually creates X problem. We help with Y.'
Persistent: 10-12 touches over 4 weeks. Most give up after 2-3.
worked_examples.outcome: You land bigger deals because you're targeting the right accounts and sticking with them long enough to break through.

daily_insights: Every conversation is a sale. You're either selling them on your idea, or they're selling you on theirs.
The person who cares least about the outcome has the most power.
Objections are just requests for more information. Welcome them.
If you're not getting rejected, you're not asking enough.
People buy from people they like, trust, and believe can help them.
The best closers ask the best questions. Shut up and listen.
Your confidence is contagious. So is your doubt.
Follow-up is where fortunes are made. Most quit too early.
Selling is serving. If you believe in your product, you owe it to them to be persistent.
Volume covers all sins. Do more, learn faster, win bigger.
In B2B sales, you're not selling to a person - you're selling to a committee. Map every stakeholder.
Busy executives buy outcomes, not products. Lead with the business impact, not features.
Consultative selling means becoming a trusted advisor. Diagnose before you prescribe.
The best enterprise deals are won before the RFP. Build relationships when they're not buying.
Specialization beats generalization. The SDR who prospects all day beats the AE who does it part-time.
skill_challenges: Make 10 cold outreach touches today. Track responses.

Send 5 follow-ups to leads you thought were dead.
Study one sales call from a master. Write down 3 techniques to steal.
Ask one open-ended question in every conversation today.
Pitch your product to yourself in the mirror with full conviction.
Identify your biggest sales weakness. Spend 20 minutes drilling it.
Map a complex deal: list every stakeholder, their priorities, and your strategy for each.
Build a prospecting cadence: design a 12-touch sequence across email, phone, and LinkedIn.
Create your Ideal Customer Profile: define the 5 characteristics of your best-fit accounts.
Track your pipeline velocity: measure days from first touch to closed deal for your last 5 wins.
Build a champion enablement deck: create materials your internal champion can use to sell for you.
